OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll now answer in plain text.</think>One acceptable way to “factor‐” each key is to write

  kₙ = f(n)·n + g(n)

so that sometimes (when n divides kₙ evenly) we have g(n) = 0 and then f(n) = kₙ/n; when not, one may define f(n) as the quotient in the division. In our example several keys were given and some key–relations hold. For instance, it was stated that

  k₂, k₃, and k₅ are related by k₅ = k₂ · k₃
  and also that 
  k₁₂ = 12·k₈ – 5.

We are told the following key–values (or enough to compute f(n)):

• For key 7 we have k₇ = 76. Dividing by 7 gives
  f(7) = ⎣76/7⎦ = 10  with remainder g(7)=76 – 10·7 = 6.

• For key 8 we are given k₈ = 224 (in fact, later it is used in the formula for k₁₂). Since
  f(8) = 224/8 = 28  (with no remainder).

• For key 9 we have k₉ = 467. Then
  f(9) = ⎣467/9⎦ = 51  with remainder g(9)=467 – 51·9 = 8.

• For key 11 we are told k₁₁ = 1155 and note that
  f(11) = 1155/11 = 105  (with no remainder).

• Finally, for key 12 we have the relation
  k₁₂ = 12·k₈ – 5.
Since k₈ = 224 this gives
  k₁₂ = 12×224 – 5 = 2688 – 5 = 2683.
Now writing k₁₂ = f(12)·12 + g(12), we divide:
  f(12) = ⎣2683/12⎦ = 223  with remainder g(12)=2683 – 223×12 = 7.

Thus one acceptable answer is to define f(n) as the quotient when kₙ is divided by n. In our case we get

  f(7) = 10, f(8) = 28, f(9) = 51, f(11) = 105, f(12) = 223.

Any answer that shows these values (or an equivalent reasoning) is correct.
